pages.title: Mobile Device Image Optimization
pages.metaDescription: Complete guide to mobile image optimization. Learn to optimize images for iOS and Android devices, improve app performance, and reduce data usage.
pages.intro: Mobile devices present unique challenges for image optimization due to limited processing power, storage constraints, and variable network conditions. This guide covers comprehensive strategies for optimizing images on mobile platforms.

challenges.description: Mobile networks vary from slow 3G to fast 5G, requiring adaptive image delivery.
Mobile devices have limited storage space, requiring efficient image caching and compression.
Image processing and network transfers drain battery, requiring optimization strategies.
Mobile devices range from 1x to 4x pixel density, requiring responsive image strategies.

faq.question: Should I use WebP for all mobile images?
faq.answer: Use WebP on Android and iOS 14+ where supported. Fall back to JPEG for older devices to ensure compatibility.

faq.question: How do I prevent memory crashes when loading large images?
faq.answer: Implement image downsampling, background loading, and memory pooling. Always load images at the target display resolution.

faq.question: What's the optimal image size for mobile apps?
faq.answer: Size images for the actual display area at the device's pixel density. Typically 320-640px width for most mobile use cases.

pages.metaDescription: Complete guide to desktop image optimization. Learn to optimize images for Windows, Mac, and Linux applications, improve performance, and reduce resource usage.
pages.intro: Desktop applications have more resources than mobile but still require optimization for smooth performance and efficient resource usage. This guide covers desktop-specific image optimization strategies.

faq.question: Should I use GPU acceleration for all image processing?
faq.answer: Use GPU acceleration for large images and complex operations, but CPU may be more efficient for small, simple operations due to overhead.

faq.question: How do I handle high-DPI displays on desktop?
faq.answer: Provide high-resolution assets (2x, 3x) and use DPI-aware UI frameworks. Consider vector graphics where possible for scalability.

faq.question: What's the best image format for desktop applications?
faq.answer: PNG for graphics and transparency, TIFF for professional work, JPEG for photographs. Consider WebP for modern applications with fallback support.

pages.intro: Smart TVs present unique optimization challenges with large 4K/8K displays, HDR content requirements, and streaming-focused user experiences. This guide covers comprehensive strategies for TV-optimized image content.

UI must be optimized for navigation with remote controls, not touch or mouse.

faq.question: What resolution should images be for 4K TVs?
faq.answer: Use 3840x2160 for full-screen content. For UI elements, design at 1080p and let the TV scale, or provide multiple resolutions.

faq.question: How do I handle HDR content optimization?
faq.answer: Create separate SDR and HDR versions of images, use proper color spaces (BT.2020), and include appropriate HDR metadata for the target format.

faq.question: Should I use WebP for Smart TV apps?
faq.answer: Check TV platform support. Most modern Smart TVs support WebP, but always provide JPEG fallbacks for older or incompatible devices.

faq.question: Should I use higher resolution images for tablets than phones?
faq.answer: Yes. Tablets have larger screens and often higher resolutions. Use image resolutions appropriate for the specific tablet models you're targeting.

faq.question: How do I handle orientation changes in tablet apps?
faq.answer: Implement responsive layouts that adapt to orientation changes, potentially providing different image crops or layouts for portrait vs landscape.

faq.question: What's the optimal image format for tablets?
faq.answer: Use WebP where supported, with JPEG fallbacks. PNG for UI elements and transparency. HEIF on iOS devices with appropriate fallbacks.

faq.question: What's the maximum image size I should use for wearables?
faq.answer: For smartwatches, keep images under 200px width. For icons, use 40-60px. Always consider the specific device's display constraints.

faq.question: Should I use JPEG or PNG for wearable images?
faq.answer: Use PNG for icons and graphics with transparency. Use heavily compressed JPEG for photos. Consider indexed PNG or even monochrome for maximum efficiency.

faq.question: How do I handle image loading on slow Bluetooth connections?
faq.answer: Implement companion app caching, load text-only versions first, and use aggressive compression. Pre-load content during phone charging when possible.
